div.head: Toward a Geographical History of Indiana: Landscape and Place in the Historical Imagination
div.p: "The muses care so little for geography." Oscar Wilde, Sententiae

Born at Terre Haute and graduated with a high school diploma from Culver Military Academy and a Ph.D. from Indiana University, I hold considerable affection for the Hoosier state. But it was in neighboring Michigan that I grew up, and for the past quarter century I have lived in adjacent Illinois , a professor of geography at the University of Illinois at Urbana - Champaign . Although mine has tended to be the view of an outsider looking in, Indiana has always struck me as a distinctive place if only in its landscapes. Take, for example, what the watchful motorist can see upon entering Indiana from the north or the east. On the secondary, or "blue highways," rights-of-way tend to be narrower in Indiana, the roads not over-engineered with the wide sweeping curves and the monotonously level straightaways of Michigan and Illinois . In Indiana highways seem to fit more readily into the passing scene. Signs crowd the roads as do fences and, frequently, houses and other buildings (Figures 1 and 2).

Except when seen from the freeways the Indiana countryside seems to be resisting modernism. There is a kinship with the past evident in the smaller scale of things, even new things, pushed close to Indiana roads. Could such differences be symptomatic of things profound? What might they mean to students of Indiana's past? To me they have always suggested at the very least that Indiana may be more like Kentucky than its other neighbors. Could this be true? If so, is it important? Surely the state's settlement history must reflect vividly in its contemporary landscapes. Or is that conclusion merely the wishful thinking of a geographer overly anxious to see contemporary landscapes as a kind of archive capable of exposing the past to view?

figure.p: Fig. 1. Fences and signs closely line many Indiana highways, helping to define for the state a "sense of place" rooted as much in past as in contemporary technologies.
Fig. 2. Houses elbow one another close to U. S. 40 at East Germantown .

div.p: One can see subtle differences as well in Indiana's small towns. Highways tend to crunch through the centers of Indiana places, often right down Main Street. Unlike Illinois , Indiana has not been so preoccupied with bypasses, both those that skirt downtowns and those that skirt towns altogether. In Illinois one has to make an effort to get to the center of things, but in Indiana one is deposited there as a matter of course. Only around the major cities, and usually only on the freeways, can travelers practice urban avoidance in the Hoosier state. I think that in Indiana there is a definite temporal rhythm to travel, a rhythm often readily noticeable in the configuration of the roads themselves. Across the center of the state U. S. 40 expands and contracts its width at the closely spaced towns, places originally positioned to serve the wagon traffic of the old National Road (Figure 3). What might this mean? Should we care?

figure.p: Fig. 3. U. S. 40 constricts at the center of Lewistown, the narrow hilltop Main Street visible for miles when approaching from both east and west.

div.p:
The conservative influences in Indiana that minimize expenditures on public rights-of-way seemingly sustain as well minimum interference in the use of adjacent private property. A tradition of weak land use control through zoning and other devices has produced in Indiana towns and cities profound temporal juxtapositions. From the most recent convenience store, car wash, or drive-in bank, one can trace back decade by decade the history of a town at a single glance. Mixed in and showing through the more recent layers of built environment at town centers are automobile showrooms relic from the 1950s, chain stores from the 1920s, lodge halls and opera houses from the 1870s, and, often, a tavern or a hotel
from before the Civil War. As Hoosier Scott Russell Sanders (1989, p. 5) notes, Indiana is "a hodgepodge of contradictory visions."

Indiana towns display time depth not because they have been fossilized as museums at some distant time (of course, the state does have its share of such places) but because changes manifested over the decades stand vividly portrayed in the juxtapositioning of diverse things, each surviving from a different warp in time. Indiana towns seem to share a subtle style of weaving together such fabrics. Pastness in landscape is a visible accumulation of overlapping traces from successive periods, each trace modifying and modified to form a collage of no single period (Jakle and Wilson, 1992, p. 15). What remains are varying design vocabularies, each reflecting off the others to give a sense of cumulative temporal depth.

Indiana's landscapes thus tend to invite careful reading. The state's built environments are, by and large, rich texts. What probably should excite historians most, of course, are the places where encrustations of the state's earliest decades persist relatively little influenced by more contemporary development (as in the older portion of the city of Madison ) or, additionally, where they are deliberately contrived to be "historic" (as at New Harmony ). These are the obvious places where "history" is in the process of being spared the ravages of modernization (or, at least, the intrusiveness of many modern things) or where pastness is being overtly contrived. Change in these places involves strong "rearview mirror vision" (Figure 4). Old horizons are being rejuvenated and given extended
Fig. 4. Madison on the Ohio River offers relic townscapes highly reminiscent of early and mid-nineteenth-century origins. Here are built environments quintessentially "historical."
life. A new horizon is being configured to complement the old by strongly suggesting pastness. Where historic preservation thrives, people have learned to read their landscapes for intrinsic values, aesthetic and otherwise. Discovery has been followed by investment, perhaps the most meaningful form of historical landscape affirmation in American society.

Why have the historians of Indiana proven so little interested in reading the state's built environments? Why is there so little emphasis on landscape as a kind of text? Can students of Indiana history not see the landscape as a depository of historical facts, a kind of archive to be tapped? Why are they not more sensitive to the symbolisms of material culture? The built environment results from human enterprise. Once formed, however, the built environment influences subsequent enterprise. It is a social production that helps engender further production in continuing rounds of symbiotic relationship. Why have Indiana historians been slow to grasp this basic organizing fact? Of course, there are some who have accepted the challenge. Thomas J. Schlereth (1985) in celebrating Indiana's U. S. 40, for example, has laid a savvy base from which to engender comprehension of Indiana's landscapes generally. But can many others be brought on board? That certainly is my objective here.

I offer in this essay focus on the concept of landscape, specifically those aspects of landscape that I call the built environment. Landscape is an idea useful in tying human events to the realities of place. This is a lesson learned relatively recently by historical and cultural geographers, and it is the viewpoint that I would pass along to students of Indiana history as they grapple with the essence of their state as geographical context. What follows is a brief assessment of how historians traditionally have viewed geography and a brief outline of human geography's growth as a discipline, emphasizing historical and cultural geography as sub-disciplines increasingly formed around the study of landscapes. Finally, through an explicit review of the literature, embracing the works of both historians and geographers, I outline the makings of a geographical history focused on Indiana.
GEOGRAPHY AND HISTORY

Most historians are quick to say how important geography is to the study of history. By this endorsement they generally refer to physical geography or natural environment viewed as neutral context. "Geography is the stage upon which history is acted," many historians affirm. Such is the old truism. But few historians seem to recognize that messages are embedded in the stage by human action and that those messages, hardly neutral at all, serve to influence subsequent action. Props invested with strong meanings carry much of the play's communication. Theater is made in
telligible not only by the spoken lines and the body language of the actors but as well by the spatial structuring of the stage set—by the sense of place created on stage. It is, therefore, not physical geography but human geography that should count the most—the human geography of strong social meanings manifested as the material culture of built environment.

Can the history of Indiana be fully written without concern for the diversity of its places—the places variously defined at different geographical scales that have comprised the Indiana experience? Can the story be fully told without focus on the processes that created specific kinds of places as generic habitats? Can historians ignore specific localities? How was it to confront wilderness in the creation of a farm? How was it to spare wilder places in arresting farm, town, and city development in the creation of state parks and forests? How was it to live in a time of thriving small towns? How was it to experience the collapse of a once viable city neighborhood? Progress and failure, the stuff of historical change, has played out in real places in Indiana with names like Pigeon Roost, Conner Prairie, Turkey Run, Gas City,
Muncie, Indianapolis, Fountain Square.

Too many historians have a tendency to conceptualize "history" as something a spatially suspended. History is reified as courses of events or as trajectories of occurrence devoid of geographical anchoring. It is a story told largely in terms of personalities and institutions divorced from the realities of place. Thus Indiana history—the history of events of the state—is removed intellectually from the underpinnings of location and the myriad relationships that hinge on locational context. What did the physical isolation of a region or a city neighborhood mean in the politics of an era? How did a town's ability to compete in Indiana's evolving system of railroad connectivity (or highway connectivity) drive some political agendas forward and retard others? How were key personalities formed by the circumstances of spatial proximity to (or spatial isolation from) significant others in the places where decisions were made? These are the sorts of questions that are too often overlooked in the neglect of the geographical dimension.

When geography is embraced by scholars, it is too often viewed as an explaining variable in a simplistic deterministic sense. Proximity may be hypothesized as explaining political influence, but proximity is never the lone factor to drive influence in political networks. It is a modifying or modified variable in its conjunction with other variables. Geographical factors are inherently enabling rather than directly causal. A state's circulation system provides a framework for action, but actions vary according to individual and group competencies at overcoming the frictions of distance and at gaining accessibility to places (and people) of influence. Isolation may invite certain kinds of perceptions important in modifying behavior,
but isolation, among other geographical variables, cannot determine human activity. Geography influences according to the cultural values, the social, political, and economic competencies, and the technical skills of people.

Historians tend not to consider geographical variables as worthy of explanation. They do not take geography as a thing in and of itself worthy of explanation. Such is fully reasonable, for if historians take geography as intellectually compelling ahead of history (or the study of historical change), they become geographers. Seeing the environment's spatial aspects as something to be explained, rather than as something offering explanation, is the preoccupation of academic geography. Advocated here, however, is a blending of the geographical and historical viewpoints—the historian's concern with pattern or changing pattern over time and the geographer's concern with pattern or changing pattern over space. Advocated here is a historical geography or geographical history that blends the two viewpoints without the one totally subverting the other.

Historians have not been alone in neglecting the geographical underpinnings of human life. According to certain social theorists, historical explanation has traditionally dominated both the humanities and the social sciences to the near exclusion of spatial or geographical viewpoints (Soja, 1989). Explanations sought have been linear. Emphasis has been on change, the seeking of cause and effect relationships across linear chronologies of perceived occurrence. Explanations have not been lateral, the seeking of explanatory relationships in surrounding contexts. Explanations tend not to mix the linear or the historical with the lateral or the geographical. Such was the power of modernist science bootlegged into the study of the human experience in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. In today's postmodernist era such simplified explanatory stances have fallen out of fashion if only temporarily. Diversity of approach has come to the forefront. The need to place human behavior carefully in spatial context as well as to seek historical explanation is now recognized.
HUMAN GEOGRAPHY

The study of geography is, itself, both old and new. Introduced in the early nineteenth century in the United States was an encyclopedic version of geography that emphasized place locations and offered descriptions of their physical and economic characteristics among other facts. School children were asked: What is the capital of Indiana? What are the state's principal rivers? What are its principal crops and where are they grown? Produced were gazetteers and atlases but few major theoretical treatises around which a substantive discipline could be based. Important ideas that did surface tended to be ignored as, for example, George Perkins
Marsh's concern with the human wasting of natural resources (Lowenthal, 1958). Geography was thus dropped from the curriculum at many major colleges and universities to be reintroduced in the early twentieth century first as the study of landforms. Before separate geography departments were formed, geography tended to be nurtured in geology departments with the concern for geomorphology or the study of landform formation preeminent. New questions were asked, now of college students. How were river valleys formed? Along the banks of Indiana's Wabash , for example, what were the mechanics of bluff erosion, terrace formation, river meander?

Human geography initially emerged as the study of environmental influences on humankind, an extension of the study of the physical environment itself. A blatant environmental determinism temporarily dominated whereby human behavior was seen to be regulated by environment. The first distinctly "historical geography" emerged in this context driven by such luminaries as Ellsworth Huntington (1907) and Ellen Churchill Semple (1903 and 1911). They saw such factors as climatic change or the physical isolation of mountain landscapes as determining the courses of human action. This was a brand of geographical scholarship that some leading historians championed. For example, Frederick Jackson Turner (1894 and 1914) in examining the impact of the western frontier on American society and politics bootlegged "environmental influences" into both his frontier thesis and his examination of sectionalism. This orientation informed substantially the work of John D. Barnhart, a historian focused on the frontier's liberalizing influences on Indiana and other state governments in the Old Northwest (and with whom I had the privilege of studying history while a graduate student at Indiana University).

Data available from census and other sources engendered in the 1920s another kind of human geography focused on the functional organization of geographical space. There emerged a strong reliance on regionalization, a preoccupation perhaps analogous to the historian's embracing of periodization (Jakle, 1971). Regional geography, which sought to understand the world according to regional differences and similarities, produced descriptive narratives supported by the use of descriptive statistics. How might Indiana be divided into regions? What distinguished southern Indiana from other parts of the state in farming, in manufacturing, in religious preference, in demographic characteristics? The 1960s brought use of inferential statistical analysis and mathematical modeling oriented to theory building (Johnston, 1983). How might the size and distribution of Indiana's cities be explained as a system? How could regularities be mathematically described? What was the influence of Indianapolis in the state's system of "central places"? And how did Indianapolis relate to Chicago ? Or to New York ? Most human
geographers naively assumed the stance of the social scientist. Only historical geographers and cultural geographers tended to decline the social science invitation in their continued orientation to the humanities.

Deductive modeling in economic geography sought strong predictive capabilities. Assumptions about human rationality were built into models to explain, using aggregated data, location decisions relative to retail stores, factories, and other sorts of businesses. For example, it was assumed that decision makers always operated from full information, thus sought to minimize costs and maximize profits. It was as if Indiana farmers always sought to grow the most profitable crops on the basis of complete if not perfect market information or that Indiana industrialists, always sought the optimal locations where labor, land, transport, and other costs were completely minimized. A kind of economic determinism came to the fore whereby "economic man" deliberately rendered a fully rational world measured largely in dollars and cents. Whole categories of human experience were ignored for no other reason than the impossibility of quantitatively measuring variables and introducing them into theoretical constructs. Synthesizing treatments of human behavior and study of derived landscape consequences continued to fall to historical and cultural geographers who remained largely unwed to scientism.
HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL GEOGRAPHY

Historical geography reemerged in the 1930s primarily as the study of regions changing over time (see: Norton, 1984). Its advocates saw in its practice the posing of the great questions of academic history in geographical context (Clark, 1954). Whereas historical geography was intended to reach out to history, cultural geography was intended to reach out to anthropology, and the concept of culture became its organizing idea. Culture was seen to manifest itself in the built environment as "material culture." The landscape, in other words, was seen to reflect culture as "cultural landscape." Culture regions could be defined according to the ways in which significant culture traits, tangible and intangible, proved mappable. Historical geography and cultural geography developed a strong affinity for one another. Explanation in both was usually based on historical analysis. Both were preoccupied with geographical change. Historical narrative was the primary media of communication.

Unfortunately, a kind of cultural determinism was brought to the fore in cultural geography. Culture, as a kind of superorganic, could not really be defined nor, accordingly, effectively measured (Duncan, 1980). Cultural geographers, however, were not deterred from adopting deterministic stances relative to explanations rendered. Things that reflected "culture" in landscape were assumed
to be explained by the reflection—to stand as culture's surrrogates. The temple-front Greek Revival houses of northern Indiana spoke of a Yankee culture area extended westward from upstate New York and Ohio carrying clear value implications rooted in religion and education. The Georgian-plan houses of the Quakers and other settlers from the Middle States across central Indiana told other stories as did the so-called "1-houses" built by Kentuckians and Virginians throughout southern Indiana (Figure 5). Culture was
Fig. 5. An "I-house" east of Raleigh carries Classical Revival ornamentation: a clear symbol of affluence and high social status, especially in southern Indiana. seen to determine differences and similarities that were observed from place to place. One might conclude that determinism, whether environmental, economic, or cultural, seemed to develop whenever simple cause and effect relationships were sought.

Two philosophical stances loom today as organizing frameworks sustaining contemporary human geography—orientations that can potentially overcome deterministic fallacies and, at the same time, foster both rigorous modeling and descriptive synthesis. They are structuration theory and symbolic interaction theory. It is my belief that historical and cultural geography in the future will rely heavily on both, or on variations of the two intertwined.

Structuration theory posits that human behavior can only be understood by looking both at individual actors and at the social structures through which individuals drive action (Giddens, 1984). There is no vague cultural determinism here. Geographical decision making, for example, is seen to reflect both individual prerog-
atives in accessing options and making locational choices and the institutional contexts through which these options are defined, evaluated, and acted upon. There was a spatial logic that drove the locating of steel mills in what quickly became the city of Gary. It had to do with the costs of assembling raw materials and distributing product as well as the costs of securing capital and labor. But there was nothing impelling about it. It was not a "natural" process of development. Rather, it resulted from specific decision makers operating within specific institutions—for example, Judge Elbert H. Gary within the U. S. Steel Corporation and that corporation's dominance of the American steel market.

Culture enters as the value sets that enable institutions to function. Cultural landscape, in turn, is seen both to reflect past decision making and to be part of the context influencing present decision making. It is both a social construction and molder of future constructions. The concept of place comes to the fore in that all human behavior is place oriented or place contained. Place construction and the use of places is integral to society's structuring and functioning. That the USX Corporation has an extensive steel mill at Gary with a particular technology mix lodged in a specific productive network of facilities constitutes a profound institutional fact. How corporate managers drive the company's future development will substantially reflect existing corporate geography.

Symbolic interactionism posits that society is the sum total of all interactions. Emphasis is placed on the process of communication whereby social realities are negotiated (Strauss, 1964). Important for students of landscape, of course, is the idea that the built environment contains messages that serve to direct or channel human behaviors. These messages help define places as appropriate contexts for action. Expectations develop as regards place appropriateness based, in part, on the kinds of messages embedded in the environment. Historical analysis, therefore, turns to understanding how place meanings have attached to landscapes in the defining of meaningful contexts for action. Historical geographical analysis turns to understanding changing place meanings over time (Jakle, 1990).

Indianapolis symbolizes much that is Hoosier. The city is the political focus of the state and substantially the economic focus as well (Figure 6). But the city's new downtown geography of convention and conference centers, of sports arenas, and of shopping malls speaks of wide-ranging symbolism—of life styles rooted in leisure time consumption (Figure 7). Who created this geography—this symbolism of place? Who consumes it? How is the dialectic between production and consumption driven? Why do old warehouses restored and horse-drawn carriages reintroduced on downtown streets figure so prominently? What is the history of this communication that redefines Indianapolis as a place?

figure.p: Fig. 6. Indianapolis , located centrally in the state through political edict, was reinforced by roads and then by railroads and modern highways radiating outward: a profound geographical fact influencing Indiana's development greatly.

div.p:
There are, perhaps, two brands of historical geography today. One, sometimes called historical cultural geography, is built around the study of changing cultural landscapes. That is the brand that I emphasize here. The other is linked directly to the scholarship of economic historians. Formed around the work of Andrew H. Clark and many of his students at the University of Wisconsin , this latter emphasis seeks to contribute to discussions ongoing in history, primarily economic history. Clark and his students have explored for selected time periods and regions the issue of Europe Overseas—in other words, the transfer of capitalistic economy, its related values, and its technologies in the settling of North America (see: Gibson, 1978). Clark brought a certain rigor to historical geographical research, instilling in his students strong
Fig. 7 Architecture around Indianapolis 's Monument Circle signifies much about Indiana's social, economic, and political stratification. archival proclivities. Less emphasized was field observation although some of Clark's proteges have gone on to rely heavily on field observation in the study of landscape.

The word "landscape," which dates back to the seventeenth century, originally referred to scenes painted by artists (for elaboration see: Cosgrove, 1984, p. 16; Jakle, 1987). Slowly the word's meaning began to change to include that which might be seen when looking out across an actual expanse of territory. Society's elites, especially in England , began to compete in creating "landscapes" contrived to look like paintings. Compositional devices were developed to render park-like, pastoral scenes that spoke of affluence, power, and prestige. In the late twentieth century the term landscape has come to refer to the actual material structuring of place. A landscape, in this sense, serves as a container structured both by natural processes (natural landscape) and by social forces (cultural landscape).

Today the name John B. Jackson (1980, 1984) is closely associated with the study of landscape (see: Meinig, 1979a) although it was from the geographer Carl 0. Sauer, and such essays as his "The Morphology of Landscape" (19251, that many of Jackson 's ideas originated. In establishing in the 1950s the influential magazine Landscape, which he dedicated to interpreting built environments, Jackson took as his guiding principle the idea that landscapes were to be read and evaluated according to function. He deliberately deemphasized the visual and, as a corollary, the landscape's aesthetic aspects. It is the cultural landscape taken as a structured container for human activity that counts. The landscape concept has given human geographers a tangible subject matter upon which to focus inquiry. Human geography no longer remains solely the study of regions or locational decision making or human spatial organizations—all abstract ideas—but is, additionally, the study of humankind's landscape surroundings as they contain and symbolize.
GEOGRAPHICAL HISTORY

What would be the major dimensions of landscape study appropriate to a historical geography or geographical history of Indiana? Of existing scholarship focused on the United States , what might be recommended as suggestive templates? What sorts of researches have already focused on Indiana? The remainder of this essay I dedicate to outlining what an emergent literature might contain. I organize my thoughts under the following labels: (1) physical or natural environment, (2) cultural values in environmental cognition, (3) migration, cultural diffusion, and the settling process, (4) social organization and place, and (5) material culture and evolving built environment. All of these emphases inform the landscape idea. They are not mutually exclusive, merely convenient categories for assessing what is a large and diverse literature. I will also recommend major works that offer syntheses of several of these major historical-geographical themes. I do not pretend a complete coverage in my selection of examples. I intend only to be suggestive.
Physical or Natural Environment

Human life is restricted primarily to the surface of the planet earth. Human history is essentially enveloped there. Every aspect of the planet's physical being, including its human population, is integrally linked ecologically. In its most essential aspect history is the story of humankind's coming to grips with its environment. Homo sapiens first emerged as an environmentally specialized organism ultimately dominating larger and larger ecological niches through the embracing of increasingly sophisticated technologies and modes of social organization. That the first Europeans to in-
trude upon what would ultimately become Indiana possessed advanced technologies (for example, a grain- and animal-based agriculture) as well as advanced social institutions (for example, a market economy organized on capitalistic principles) does not negate the need to consider the physical or natural environment as inherently enabling and/or restricting. True, the Europeans were more "sophisticated in their cultural baggage than Native Americans (and thus not as "close to nature"), but physical environment still remained something very much to be accommodated. The environment presented resistances to be overcome with some locations and some areas better endowed naturally for one or another sort of intended change. Differences in landform, drainage, vegetation, soil, and climate informed human successes and failures place to place over time. Where then would a historian turn to comprehend the outlines of natural or physical environment?

Indiana geologist William D. Thornbury's Regional Geomorphology of the United States
(1967), as well as Nevin M. Fenneman's Physiography of Eastern United States
(1938), offers introduction to Indiana's topography. Basic climatic patterns gauged from a century or more of accurate observation can be gleaned from both the U. S. Department of Commerce's Climatic Atlas of the United States
(1964) and Indiana geographer Stephen S. Visher's Climatic Atlas of the United States
(1954). Henry A. Gleason's and Arthur Cronquist's The Natural Geography of Plants (1964) and John L. Vankat's The Natural Vegetation of North America: An Introduction (1979) provide orientation to biogeography. For soils one might start with Francis D. Hole's and James B. Campbell's Soil Landscape Analysis (1985). May T. Watts's Reading the Landscape: An Adventure in Ecology (1957) is an excellent guide to interpreting nature in landscape. Armed with these overviews the historian should possess the rudiments with which to pursue questions of environmental "influence."

Comprehension of basic physical geography can only inform understanding of changing human response. How might an impermeable claypan in a soil have retarded grain cultivation at a specific time and place? How might such conditions have impacted the viability of farm trade centers in an area? How might topography have informed route selection and hence road networking? How might route selection have warped the urban network favoring some locations over others? Although would-be geographical historians should necessarily look beyond the physical environment in studying urban patterns, they, nonetheless, should anchor questions on comprehensions rooted there.
Cultural Values and Environmental Cognition

More important than understanding past physical environment per se is comprehending how historical actors or agents of
change actually conceptualized those environments. It is not the world as it was so much as the world as it was thought to have been. What were the beliefs, attitudes, and intentionalities that underlay nature's assessment? What were the behavioral proclivities brought by various kinds of people to nature's modification? Conceptualizing nature, of course, is but a subset of a larger concern. How do people conceptualize their total surroundings as geography? How do these conceptions influence behavior? Once nature has been modified—a wilderness exploited, the land cultivated, towns and cities sustained commercially, political territories established—then the environment is substantially a social construct. As physical manifestation it stands as cultural rather than as natural landscape. How then are cultural landscapes assessed? Specifically, how are places assigned meanings, and how do these meanings change over time?

Places are loci of meaning. Indianapolis , I have suggested, is not only a physical place—a container of human activities—but it is a symbolic thing suggesting and thus inviting human intentionality. Behavioral expectations, negotiated in the continuous rounds of symbolic interaction (Denzin, 19921, attach to places. As I have said, society in this view stands as the sum total of all communications—from the highly personalized face-to-face messages at one end of the communication spectrum to highly impersonal "to whom it may concern" messages embedded in the fabric of the built environment. Social reality is constantly renegotiated through interaction. Places take meaning at various spatial scales, from that of personal spaces enveloping closely the individual to the spaces of rooms and whole buildings as architecture to that which is more recognizably "geographical" as defined at neighborhood, district, or regional levels. Researchers in behavioral geography and environmental psychology among other disciplines have produced an extensive literature given to environmental cognition. Excellent syntheses have been written by Irwin Altman (1975) and Thomas F. Saarinen (1984).

The historian might be better oriented to environmental cognition through works focused directly on cultural values. John K. Wright's Human Nature in Geography (1966), a seminal philosophical statement, and David Lowenthal's and Martyn J. Bowden's edited festschrift in Wright's honor (1976) are highly recommended. Clearly reflective of the closure between values and landscape are works by historians including William Cronon's Changes in the Land: Indians, Colonists, and the Ecology of New England
(1983), Roderick Nash's Wilderness and the American Mind (19821, and Leo Marx's The Machine in the Garden: Technology and the Pastoral Ideal in America (1964). Focus on the symbolism of place plays out in such diverse but related works as Henry Nash Smith's Virgin Land: The American West as Symbol and Myth (1950) and
Annette Kolodny's The Lay of the Land: Metaphor as Experience and History in American Life and Letters (1975). How do different kinds of people assess places of different sorts differently? How does it all translate into changing landscape? A concise outline of this intellectual challenge appears as "The Beholding Eye: Ten Versions of the Same Scene" by Donald W. Meinig in his edited volume The Interpretation of Ordinary Landscapes (1979b).
Migration, Cultural Diffusion, and the Settling Processes

As regards Indiana landscapes, perhaps the most important historical period was that of initial effective American settlement. Political, economic, and social templates were cast that would drive and substantially mold subsequent development. Systems of land survey, land sales, and land tenure along with systems of political jurisdiction and market regulation were introduced, all of which would give substantive form to the built environment. People attracted variously from the south and east (and directly from Europe as well) would impose varying cultural templates (Figure 8). Much of the initial impress of field patterns, road and streets, and other residuals reflecting early property division can still be seen in most contemporary Indiana landscapes for subsequent overlays and modifications have all been made on the base levels of initial settlement.

Historians have had a penchant for focusing on pioneering through the search for cultural origins. The frontier or pioneer era
Fig. 8. Settlers from the Upper South impacted cultural landscapes across the state as this sign near Lebanon testifies.
has excited several excellent geographical histories in recent years, which works build, in turn, on a genre of scholarship largely associated with Frederick Jackson Turner and his students. John Mack Faragher's Sugar Creek: Life on the Illinois
(1986) looks at pioneer appraisal of a central Illinois locale and details the transition from a subsistence agricultural economy highly dependent upon the hunt toward a commercial corn and hog agriculture reinforced by railroads and market towns. Michael J. OBrien's Grassland, Forest, and Historical Settlement (1984) is more decidedly geographical in that he carefully traces the changing spatial organization of a Missouri frontier community, detailing initial settlement and subsequent settlement maturation as a reflection, in part, of soil, slope, drainage, and vegetation differences. A migration stream is carefully documented back to Kentucky with emphasis placed on the cultural values and technologies transferred to Missouri . How did early settlers appraise the physical environment? How did this appraisal inform land claims and early patterns of settlement distribution? How did success and failure on the land, in part a function of choices made, influence material culture? The work of Wayne E. Keifer (1969) on Rush County , Indiana, is of a similar vein.

For Indiana there has been a long standing interest in migration and cultural diffusion resulting in the mapping of population dispersals across the state over time. Richard L. Power's Planting Corn Belt Culture (1953) has been followed recently by a spate of articles by historians and geographers: James M. Bergquist (1981) and Gregory S. Rose (1985, 1986, and 1991). Folklorists, geographers, and other scholars have begun to sketch the outlines of nineteenth-century material culture residual from these different culture groups (southerners versus Yankees for example): Warren Roberts (1984) with log architecture, Robert W. Bastian (1975) with common houses, and John Fraser Hart (1968) with field patterns. An introduction to the analysis of material culture at the landscape scale may be had in Thomas J. Schlereth's Cultural History and Material Culture: Everyday Life and Material Culture (1992). The classic statement tying vernacular architecture to cultural diffusion remains Fred Kniffen's "Folk Housing: Key to Diffusion" (1965).
The Social Organization of Place

How is it that society organizes itself geographically? Human geographers have taken as their goal the discovery of spatial or
geographical order produced by and, in turn, producing social order (Figure 9). Things, people, and their activities relate in places.
Fig. 9. Racism plays out in Indianapolis and other cities through the operation of "dual housing markets": African Americans and other minorities given differential treatment in locating residences. Distinctive neighborhoods result. Places defined at various scales link, often hierarchically, in highly patterned ways. The historian moving to embrace place-oriented explanation would do well to investigate the literature on human territoriality; for example, Robert D. Sack's Human Territoriality: Its Theory and History (1986) and E. Gordon Ericksen's The Territorial Experience: Human Ecology as Symbolic Interaction (1980). The place concept is broadened in Yi-Fu Tuan's Space and Place: The Perspective of Experience (1977). For an excellent anthology which brings together recent work focused on place-oriented behavior see John A. Agnew's and James S. Duncan's edited The Power of Place: Bringing Together Geographical and Sociological Imaginations (1989).

Historians as well as geographers have long been concerned with the region (or section) as a kind of place (see Turner, 1932, and Jensen, 1951). How have political tensions rooted in different cultural values emerged through different economic orientations? Geographers have asked a wide variety of related questions. Wilbur Zelinsky in his The Cultural Geography of the United States
(1992) explores the varied ways that cultural differences historically have played out to define cultural regions in the United States . Ann R. Markusen, an economist, focuses directly on the economics
of spatial organization at the regional scale in her Region: The Economics and Politics of Territory (1987). James R. Short-ridge, on the other hand, looks at the history of the Middle West as an idea in his Middle West: Its Meaning in American Culture (1989). How and why have regions attracted people and investment differentially? How has power been exercised vis-a-vis differing political proclivities regionally defined? How has regionalism traditionally operated in a state like Indiana? The question of how Indiana divides into perceptual regions or sections remains to be fully answered.

Neighborhood represents another kind of geographical referent long important to the work of historians (Figure 10). James R.
Fig. 10. The towers of Roman Catholicism rise on Evansville 's westside, an icon of Germania. A still viable German -American presence spreads outward across Vanderburgh and adjacent Posey counties. Perry's recent The Formation of a Society on Virginia 's Eastern Shore, 1615–1655 (1990) is an excellent case study concerned with the rise of community defined around rural neighborhoods. For the
urban context Kathleen N. Conzen's Immigrant Milwaukee , 1836–1860: Accommodation and Community in a Frontier City (1976) and Olivier Zunz's The Changing Face of Inequality: Urbanization, Industrial Development, and Immigrants in Detroit , 1880–1920 (1982) are exceptionally fine case studies, again conceptualized substantially around issues of society and place. Spatial distribution, spatial organization, and the spatial behavior of people within and between places receives substantive emphasis. How and why did immigrant populations cluster geographically? How did this influence socialization? For Indiana the work of Dean R. Esslinger on South Bend , Immigrants and the City: Ethnicity and Mobility in a Nineteenth-Century Midwestern Community (1975) is recommended. For an assessment of architecture and its relation to social class and status, again in an Indiana context, see Robert W. Bastian's "Architecture and Class Segregation in Late Nineteenth-Century Terre Haute , Indiana" (1975). James J. Duncan's "Landscape Taste as a Symbol of Group Identity" (1973) remains a classic statement relating social class and architectural tastes.

The spatial organization of cities, and systems of cities as they relate to territorial hinterlands, has generated substantial interest among geographers. Some of this work has been given important historical orientation. Allan R. Pred's (1966, 1973, and 1980) focus on urban dynamics applies various theoretical constructs to historic cases in both the United States and Europe and establishes a comparative analytical framework in the process. How and why has the modern system of cities evolved? David R. Meyer's "A Dynamic Model of the Integration of Frontier Urban Places into the United States System of Cities" (1980) speaks directly to this question. Why have some urban places thrived and others not in the competition for economic ascendancy? Michael P. Conzen's "The Maturing Urban System in the United States , 1840–1910" (1977) focuses on evolving banking infrastructures for answers. A broader consideration of growth/nongrowth factors appears in Edward K. Muller's "Selective Urban Growth in the Middle Ohio Valley, 1800–1860" (1976). The small town as a creature of territorial competition between railroad corporations is the topic of John C. Hudson's PZains Country Towns (1985). The reasons why Indianapolis developed into the state's largest city may seem obvious. But why did the city not rise to become the Middle West's " Chicago "?

Historians have made important contributions. William Cronon's Nature's Metropolis: Chicago and the Great West (1991) traces Chicago 's rise as a regional center back to the city's natural resource base to emphasize both commodity production and flow and related systems of finance. More specialized but nonetheless important to understanding Chicago 's evolution as an urban landscape is Harold L. Platt's The Electric City: Energy and the Growth of
the Chicago Area, 1880–1930 (1991). Platt describes the rise of competing power grids and their ultimate consolidation as a single public utility. Focus on the physical structuring of Chicago plays out in Ann Durkin Keating's Building Chicago : Suburban Developers and the Creation of a Divided Metropolis (1988). Whereas Chicago , as the major metropolis of the midcontinent, attracts such scholarly attention, much could be learned about American urban development through study of Indianapolis , perhaps a more typical American city. How has the Hoosier capital's class structure evolved in relation to the geographical structuring of work? How has Indianapolis reached out to define a hinterland? How does the Indianapolis hinterland inform Indiana's geographical development?

The research of certain urban geographers, urban sociologists, and urban planners who have focused on the contemporary city should suggest to historians hypotheses deserving historical analysis. Neil Smith, a geographer, formulates in his Uneven Development: Nature, Capital and the Production of Space (1990) how certain inequalities of development are integral to modern capitalism. Sociologists John R. Logan and Harvey L. Molotch in their Urban Fortunes: The Political Economy of Place (1987) view the development of cities in terms of local conflict over growth.
Material Culture and Evolving Built Environment

The common house is, perhaps, the most important feature of any landscape. A machine for living, the house shelters; a social symbol, the house communicates class, status, and other meanings. In the aggregate no other building type is 'so numerous. Peirce F. Lewis's "Common Houses, Culture Spoor" (1975) provides concise introduction to the study of American house types as does Allen G. Noble's book, Wood, Brick, and Stone: The North American Settlement Landscape: Vol. 1: Houses (1984). Henry H. Glassie's classic Patterns in the Material Folk Culture of the Eastern United States
(1968) focuses on folk buildings whereas Lewis and Noble embrace the vernacular of the early commercial builders as well. Jakle, Bastian, and Meyer (1989) consider a sample of small towns across the eastern United States (including Rockville , Indiana) to analyze both relic folk and builder houses and their plan form and style influences on twentieth-century house construction. The social or cultural significance of the house as home has been explored by social historians. Highly recommended is Gwendolyn Wright's Moralism and the Model Home (1979) and Jan Cohn's The Palace or the Poorhouse: The American House as a Cultural Symbol (1979).

For rural landscapes and landscape features, one might start with John Fraser Hart's The Look of the Land (1975). Hart couples introductions to barns, fences, and the other prevailing structures
of rural countryside to concern for land division, land tenure, and farm economy among other topics. The book, as one reviewer noted, might have as easily been called "How to Look at the Land." For an overview of barns, see Volume 2 of Noble's Wood, Brick, and Stone (1984). Concern with rural structures carries a certain urgency. With increased mechanization, specialization, and consolidation in Indiana agriculture much of the state's traditional rural fabric is directly threatened. As buildings are removed, Indiana faces a dwindling landscape archive from which to read the past.

As for urban examples, I will restrict my comments largely to the built environments of American retailing. Architectural historian C#2 H. Liebs's Main Street to Miracle Mile: American Roadside Architecture (1985) is one place to start for overview. Liebs traces the rise of Main Street as a retail institution and its decline in favor of commercial strips. Richard Longstreth, also an architectural historian, explores the building types of the typical American Main Street in his The Buildings of Main Street: A Guide to American Commercial Architecture (1987). Geographer Richard Francaviglia, on the other hand, examines their symbolic significances in his "Main Street USA: The Creation of a Popular Image" (1977). But nothing surpasses historian Lewis E. Ather-ton's Main Street on the Middle Border (1954) as an exploration of retailing's social functioning during the golden age of Main Street late in the nineteenth and early in the twentieth centuries. Richard L. Mattson's "Store Front Remodelling on Main Street" (1983) deals with twentieth-century modernizing in response to the rise of automobile-oriented commercial strips.

Many Indiana court seats are organized both with a Main Street and with a courthouse square, the two usually integrated at the town center. Edward T. Price's "The Central Courthouse Square in the American County Seat" (1968) and Marian M. Oh-man's "Diffusion of Foursquare Courthouses to the Midwest, 1785–1885" (1982) provide excellent introduction to the topic. Where did various plan forms originate? How were they diffused? How did they impact surroundings place to place? What did they symbolize? What did the mania for building large, spectacular courthouses symbolize for nineteenth-century Indiana (Figure 11). ORen located in squares at the core of business districts, what did they say about local community? What do replacement court buildings located off the square—and often beyond the edge of towns—have to say?

The coming of the automobile changed the American Main Street as it changed American landscapes generally. Things could be and were more spread out in geographical space. New kinds of land uses were brought into novel juxtapositions. Increased mobility drove the central place functions of retail and service trade up the hierarchy of towns and cities, leaving commercial districts in
Fig. 11. As at Mt. Vernon in Posey County , courthouses with their surrounds of monuments and signs are a kind of landscape text more readily read than most. Themes are basic to traditional political history. the smallest places largely empty and shuttered. Historians have amassed a sizeable literature on the coming of the motor car and motor truck (for example, see Flick, 1988). In thriving towns and cities automobility brought the commercial strip—an alignment of both automobile-convenient and automobile-oriented business enterprise along principal thoroughfares and peripheral highways. John A. Jakle's and Richard L. Mattson's "The Evolution of a Commercial Strip" (1982) and Kent MacDonald's "The Commercial Strip: From Main Street to Television Road" (1985) provide general introduction. For focus on specific features of the strip, see, by way of example, Warren J. Belasco's Americans on the Road: From Auto Camp to Motel, 1910–1945 (1979) or John A. Jakle's and Keith A. Sculle's The Gas Station in America: Place-Product-Packaging and Corporate Territoriality (forthcoming). What did these new landscape features signify in the larger cultural equations of American society? How were they rooted in the American past?

The highway, if not the automobile, stands symbolic of American twentieth-century landscape. From historian Frederic L. Pax-son's (1946) "The Highway Movement, 1916–1935" through
geographer Peter J. Hugill's (1982) "Good Roads and the Automobile in the United States , 1880–1929," many scholars have sought to explore the evolving American road both as structure and as symbol. Perhaps none have proven more insightful than J. Todd Snow in his "The New Road in the United States " (1967). Snow saw the limited access freeways as alienated from their surroundings—the landscape pushed back at arm's length. Travelers are no longer in the landscape as they were with the traditional road where things were accessed close at hand and where life could be viewed directly in passing. The histories of specific highways provide linear traverses through time and space. George R. Stewart's U.S. 40: Cross Section of the United States of America (1955) has attracted much praise. For Indiana, I mention once again Schlereth's U.S. 40: A Roadscape of the American Experience (1985). Important also is Drake Hokanson's The Lincoln Highway: Main Street Across America (1988).

The highway replaced the railroad as prime organizer of American geography. Railroads drove the growth of towns and cities in the mid-to-late nineteenth century as highway and air connectivity do today. Towns bypassed by railroads withered; towns served by railroads thrived according to the capacities of local entrepreneurs and the wealth of established hinterlands. Railroads influenced urban morphology. Streetcars and mass transit lines enabled high density cities and, consequently, encouraged a concentrated and fully vibrant streetlife—what Americans came to associate with the urbane. John R. Stilgoe's Metropolitan Corridor: Railroads and the American Scene (1983) focuses directly on the railroad as landscape feature, looking especially at railroad rights-of-way and adjacent land uses. Susan D. Walther's The Railroad in the American Landscape (1981) offers broader social interpretation.
Historical-Geographical Synthesis

The diligent reader who has made it through to this point in this essay will likely disparage any additional citations even though he or she may realize that whole categories of historical-geographical concern have not as yet been assigned. What of the history of cartography? What of exploration and travel? What of the role of landscape painting, lithography, and photography in depicting past landscapes and landscape change over time? Recommended are two excellent bibliographies that span completely the geography/history interface focused on North America. See Michael P. Conzen et. al., A Scholar's Guide to Geographical Writing on the American and Canadian Past (1992) and Ronald Grim, Historical Geography of the United States : A Guide to Information Sources (1982).

Before concluding, however, I would like to call attention to three additional works. These might be the first works that the
curious initiate to the study of landscape would seek to access. The first book is the initial volume of Donald W. Meinig's The Shaping of America (1986). Meinig, perhaps the leading historical geographer in the United States today, presents an intellectual scaffolding, distinctly geographical, for reassessing the evolving American experience. Focusing on European imperialism, Meinig places the colonization of North America firmly within emergent capitalism's European-centered spatial frame. Meinig is not as concerned with physical environmental underpinnings nor with emergent cultural landscapes as he is with the grand overview focused on the geographical realities of imperial strategy.

The second book is J. Carville Earle's Geographical Inquiry and American Historical Problems (1992). Earle explores, again from distinctly geographical viewpoints, central processes that have defined the American experienc—olonization, regional development and sectionalism, industrialization, and urbanization. He seeks to anchor the human actions behind historical events in the social coordinates of place. His chapters serve as clear examples of geographical history. The third book, Terry G. Jordan's and Matti E. Kaups's The American Backwoods Frontier: An Ethnic and Ecological Interpretation (1989) takes the final step. Concerned with imperial strategies and dedicated to big questions of history, Jordan and Kaup extend discussion to issues of landscape, emphasizing material culture: the steel ax and hunting rifle, the log cabin and worm fence, and corn and hog agriculture—the essence of a rapidly shifting western frontier. In these three masterworks is the story that leads directly to Indiana's settlement and the threshold of the state's modern development. These three books alone should sufficiently energize the would-be scholar of Indiana's geographical history by giving focus and meaning to landscape as an organizing intellectual construct and source of inspiration.

How does all of this sum up? As a long time aficionado of Indiana, a historical geographer, and a dedicated student of American landscape, I have attempted to showcase here relevant scholarship suggestive of, if not directly contributory to, a geographical history of the Hoosier state focused on the concerns of landscape. For those who might follow my direction a word of warning may be in order. The historian who adopts the landscape view stands to be forever diverted. The landscape will loom quickly as evocatively problematical. The features of landscape will soon provide constant intellectual referent. What is that? How did it get there? What does it mean? How does it relate to other things elsewhere? The historian will become preoccupied with the passing scene. Coming to different places (crossing state lines for example) will excite, in and of itself, basic curiosity. Things previously ignored
Fig. 12. Landscape study is an invitation to oral history. Putting down his newspaper the barber in this Roachdale shop talked at length about what made Indiana a distinctive place. will take urgency. The lid will be off of Pandora's box. The landscape will loom as a new kind of archive. The landscape will become something important, in itself worth explaining. The historian will have a whole new way of being in the world at once disturbing to old ways of thinking yet intrinsically exciting.

Americans have tended to view history as something apart from the mainstream (Lowenthal, 1985). History is viewed as past. Pastness when it survives in the contemporary scene (in the relic features of landscape, for example) is generally ignored although things truly significant from the past may be enshrined as "historic sites." Monuments may be erected to remember significant people and events, or physical fabric surviving from the past may be preserved as museum display—historic places variously contrived. Historians have traditionally aided and abetted the cultivation of a sense of history set apart from the here and now. However, coupling the traditional archive with the study of landscape may counter this tendency (Figure 12). The contemporary
landscape will become a point of departure in intellectually reconstituting past landscapes over time. As an archive of historical significance, the landscape itself will not only inspire questions but will provide some of the evidence for informed answers. Finally, historians may be turned to advocating historical values as relevant to contemporary landscapes—landscapes seen not only as unique historical displays but as lived-in places in the contemporary social milieu. History will no longer seem so essentially past. It will become something alive that encompasses and can be touched and experienced as environment. History will live in the accretions or the overlays of today's landscape.

div.head: Frederick Jackson Turner at Indiana University
div.p: In January of 1910 President William Lowe Bryan of Indiana University invited Professor Frederick Jackson Turner of the University of Wisconsin to present the school's commencement address. His choice was wise as well as courageous. It was wise because Turner was highly prestigious and, in a sense, at the pinnacle of his scholarly career. He was president of the American Historical Association, and his essay on "The Significance of the Frontier in American History," presented at the Chicago World's Columbian Exposition in 1893, had early established him a leader in the profession.1 It was courageous because, although Turner was recognized as one of the nation's premier historians, he had profoundly offended some of Wisconsin 's alumni and trustees as well as many sports fans by speaking out on the evils of intercollegiate football and insisting that the nation's colleges return to the basic idea of developing a physically fit student body rather than a small aggregate of "gladiators."2 In fact, Turner's attitude toward intercollegiate athletics and academic freedom for the faculty and his opposition to legislative pressure groups that would diminish the role of scholarly research in the humanities and social sciences eventually led him to leave Wisconsin for Harvard .

Turner was cautious about accepting President Bryan's invitation and especially concerned about the effect of his address on the welfare of the university. Unlike his earlier visit to Indiana in 1906, when he gave two historical lectures—one to the university community and the other to the history students and faculty—

Turner intended in the commencement address to combine history with exhortation and speak on the subject "Pioneer Ideals and the State University." He planned to send an advance copy of his text to his friend James A. Woodburn, senior professor of history at Indiana University. Turner invited Woodburn to "censure [sic] any sentences that might make trouble." But he went on to add: "Of course I don't agree not to keep them in … if after consultation I conclude they should stand— … I prefer as a matter of precaution to give you the opportunity to hold up any thing that seems harmful." Turner doubted that he had "any stuff that a sensational reporter might distort into trouble-making utterances. Of course," he continued, "if there are any statements or ideas that might make trouble for me though not for the University of Indiana [sic], I am willing to let them stand. I merely wish to give you a free hand in the reports to safeguard the University."3 If Woodburn made any suggestions, evidence of them is not found in their correspondence. Turner probably delivered his address as originally written.

"Pioneer Ideals and the State University" proved to be a remarkable essay in many ways.4 It was not the traditional collection of platitudes, even by early twentieth-century standards. Nevertheless, the audience probably took pleasure in Turner's paean of praise for the democratic ideology and contribution to national development that he attributed to the pioneer settlers of the Old Northwest. Their individualism, their love of democracy (which Turner never defined), their distrust of aristocracy, and their willingness to do the hard work so essential to opening a new country proclaimed the success of the frontier era. Available resources, especially land, had provided a safety valve that allowed their pioneer society to expand and further democratic institutions. But, Turner pointed out, the frontier era had passed: the time for the rule-of-thumb and the jack-of-all-trades was over. A modern industrial society required an educated electorate as well as scientifically trained experts if it hoped to prosper and to preserve its institutions. On the frontier the "first ideal of the pioneer was that of conquest." With the frontier era at a close the American people lived in an industrial urban society where, Turner insisted, the "test tube and the microscope are needed rather than the ax and the rifle."

He also excused Turner on the ground that this address was for popular consumption. Billington, himself a staunch defender of the frontier thesis, did not address the issue of public higher education. div.p: A thoughtful reading of the commencement address indicates that Turner did have some "sensational" stuff in it, especially for a Hoosier audience, even in the Progressive Era. Aside from reiterating his views on the significance of the frontier, which were then gaining almost universal credence, Turner, like many of his scientific contemporaries, warned of Malthusian consequences as the population of the world increased and the number of available resources diminished. But he was not a pessimistic doomsayer. The United States , even without a frontier of available land, was not inevitably destined to economic and political decline or, more important, to surrender its democratic institutions. To Turner, a thorough-going progressive determined to preserve middle-class, democratic institutions, the time had come to set aside the unrestrained individualism of the frontier era, when each person sought to take and use as many resources as possible in any way possible, and to replace it with an individualism that recognized the significance of the community and was willing to serve a larger good. Thus, for Turner, the time had come when the lasting democratic values of the frontier would be promoted not by the rugged individualism of E. H. Harriman, the railroad tycoon, but by university-educated men and women who would find a common ground between the competing classes in society.

Turner's essay has a remarkably contemporary quality about it, especially in an era when American society is again in transition. He understood then, as most people do today, that a new era required new skills. Turner's faith in education sounds, even after eighty years, much like what Americans are again offered as the solution to the nation's changing economy. Turner, however, went further than contemporary politicians dared: he argued that without change America's democratic institutions themselves were in jeopardy.

Professional historians, who have been quick to set Turnerian ideas in amber as of 1893, or to identify him as part of the pessimistic academic community of the turn of the century, might well reread this essay. Turner did, indeed, continue to defend his frontier thesis, but he also recognized that Americans should not attempt to preserve those attributes of the frontier that were poorly suited to the twentieth century. He believed that free public education, especially the Hoosier variety, offered a viable substitute for the frontier. It gave virtually everyone, native and immigrant, regardless of origin, access not only to the technical skills essential to prosper in the twentieth century but also to the cultural values of the dominant middle-class society on which his version of democracy was founded.

Turner's address does not rank with General George C. Marshall's commencement speech at Harvard in 1947, which spelled out the Marshall Plan for the restoration of Europe after World War 11, but it was an intellectually challenging talk that—despite some dubious historical generalizations—still warrants reading.
PIONEER IDEALS AND THE STATE UNIVERSITY.1

The ideals of a people, the aspirations and convictions, their hopes and ambitions, their dreams and determinations, are assets in their civilization as real and important as per capita wealth or industrial skill.

This nation was formed under pioneer ideals. During three centuries after Captain John Smith struck the first blow at the American forest on the eastern edge of the continent, the pioneers were abandoning settled society for the wilderness, seeking, for generation after generation, new frontiers. Their experiences left abiding influences upon the ideas and purposes of the nation. Indeed the older settled regions themselves were shaped profoundly by the very fact that the whole nation was pioneering and that in the development of the West the East had its own part.

The first ideal of the pioneer was that of conquest. It was his task to fight with nature for the chance to exist. Not as in older countries did this contest take place in a mythical past, told in folk lore and epic. It has been continuous to our own day. Facing each generation of pioneers was the unmastered continent. Vast forests blocked the way; mountainous ramparts interposed; desolate, grassclad prairies, barren oceans of rolling plains, arid deserts, and a fierce race of savages, all had to be met and defeated. The rifle and the axe are the symbols of the backwoods pioneer. They meant a training in aggressive courage, in domination, in directness of action, in destructiveness.

To the pioneer the forest was no friendly resource for posterity, no object of careful economy. He must wage a hand to hand war upon it, cutting and burning a little space to let in the light upon a dozen acres of hard won soil, and year after year, expanding the clearing into new woodlands against the stubborn resistance of primeval trunks and matted roots. He made war against the rank fertility of the soil. While new worlds of virgin land lay ever just beyond, it was idle to expect the pioneer to stay his hand and turn to scientific farming. Indeed, as Secretary Wilson has said, the pioneer would, in that case, have raised wheat that no one wanted to eat, corn to store on the farm, and cotton not worth the picking.

Thus, fired with the ideal of subduing the wilderness, the destroying pioneer fought his way across the continent, masterful
